awd_titl_txt: Conference: US-Japan Workshop: Re-thinking the Relationship between Built Environment Conditions and Health and Well-being in Changing Climatic, Social, and Technological Contexts
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant provides partial support for U.S. participants to attend a two-day workshop in Tokyo, Japan, on March 28 and 29, 2024. The workshop objectives are to 1) increase understanding of how climate, societal, and healthcare changes impact existing buildings and infrastructure, influencing future design; 2) examine how these changes affect people's health and well-being in current buildings, influencing future design; and 3) explore how artificial intelligence (AI) can help analyze relevant complex relationships and evaluate AI's role in this context. Kyushu University, a top research institution in Japan, will host the workshop. Japan's vulnerability to climate change and its challenge to achieve carbon neutrality make it a key arena for finding creative solutions and working together internationally to tackle urgent environmental and climate challenges. Japan's unique social and cultural characteristics can offer different perspectives and innovative solutions. Additionally, Kyushu University's interdisciplinary expertise in various engineering fields and its commitment to sustainability make it an ideal host for the workshop. The conference will bring together experts from different fields to collaborate on sustainable building design and engineering. This diversity of expertise will provide valuable insights and drive innovation in addressing sustainability challenges and human well-being in the built environment.

Recent changes in climate, society, and technology will impact how buildings are designed and engineered. These changes bring both challenges and opportunities. First, climate change will lead to the need for more resilient and healthier buildings to cope with extreme heat and climate change-related health challenges. Secondly, societal changes like sustainability, environmental awareness, and an aging population will shape how buildings will be designed, engineered, and operated. Thirdly, advancements in healthcare will influence how buildings are designed to promote health and well- being. Lastly, artificial intelligence (AI) breakthroughs can transform building design and engineering. The collaborative discussion among U.S. and Japanese researchers and scholars at the workshop will enable the exchange of knowledge and ideas, facilitating potential breakthroughs in building science and human health. The diverse expertise will provide an environment for formulating comprehensive solutions and advancing collective understanding of sustainable buildings, improving society, and promoting global cooperation in environmental sustainability and human health.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The workshop project was funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) under Grant Number 2401864, awarded to Louisiana State University in 2023. The workshop explored the relationship between built environments and human health in the context of extreme weather events and societal and technological trends. The discussions focused on understanding how extreme weather events affect the built environment, energy systems, and human health and well-being while also identifying ways data analytics can help improve built environment sustainability and resilience.

The project includes two workshops. The first workshop, held on March 28-29, 2024, took place at the Nihonbashi Life Science Building in Tokyo, Japan, in collaboration with Kyushu University. The event featured keynote addresses, research presentations, panel discussions, breakout sessions, and a poster session. Participants included senior researchers, postdoctoral fellows, and graduate students from the United States and Japan, representing fields such as environmental engineering, atmospheric sciences, built environment design and engineering, healthcare, and data science. Discussions covered a broad range of issues, from extreme weather-induced risks to building adaptation and resilience. The second workshop, a follow-up event, held at the University at Albany, NY, on July 18-19, 2024, built upon the Tokyo discussions with a focus on extreme weather events, data-driven resilience strategies, and exposome (i.e., the totality of environmental exposures) in the built environment. This follow-up event refined research priorities through thematic panel discussions, breakout sessions, and a group strategy session. Participants examined the integration of atmospheric environmental science, health research, and engineering solutions to strengthen built environment design, engineering, and operation.

The workshops explored the impact of extreme weather on built environment systems, energy infrastructure, and public health. Participants discussed the growing challenges posed by natural hazards such as heatwaves, emphasizing the need for proactive planning to improve adaptation. The strain on energy infrastructure was also a key topic, with discussions highlighting the need for more reliable and accessible energy systems. In addition, participants examined how buildings can be better adapted to extreme weather events, focusing on the role of design, materials, and operational strategies in ensuring long-term sustainability.

Beyond infrastructure, the workshops also addressed challenges in data and modeling, emphasizing the need for improved real-time and long-term data collection and predictive analytics to support better decision-making. Considering how different communities are affected by extreme weather, the participants emphasized the need for tailored, community-specific adaptation strategies. The workshops also explored personalized adaptation, discussing how individuals experience and respond to extreme weather and the role of technology in supporting adaptation efforts. Throughout these discussions, participants emphasized the importance of interdisciplinary collaboration, data-driven approaches, and policy engagement in building climate resilience.

The project successfully facilitated discussions on extreme weather events, human health, and the built environment, as well as their relationships. The findings emphasized the importance of re-aligning environmental data, health metrics, and computational modeling to develop effective built environment design, engineering, and operation methods and strategies in the new contexts imposed by stressors in climatic, social, and technological systems. The project has also identified the need to refine these insights through collaborative studies, funding applications, and policy engagement to enhance built environment sustainability, resilience, and public health outcomes. These efforts will contribute to the development of sustainable built environments that improve human well-being.
